newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks end down on golds, profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks end down on golds, profit-taking.

text.p: Toronto stocks ended weaker on Thursday after a brisk session in which investors grabbed profits from a high-flying bank sector.
Precious metal stocks were also depressed by sharply lower gold futures which sank to fresh three-year lows.
The TSE 300 Index fell 17.95 points to close at 5304.62, but the key index still hit a new intraday high of 5326.88 earlier in the session.
"Gold stocks were down and we also had some ominous selling in the banks," said Rolie Bradley, an institutional salesman for Maison Placements Canada Inc.
Trading was heavy with nearly 110 million shares exchanging hands for a value of C$1.57 billion (US$1.1 billion).
Gains in eight of 14 sub-groups could not offset sharp losses in precious metals and financial services.
The gold group surrendered 250 points as COMEX gold futures sank on IMF plans to sell some of its gold reserve to help fund Third World debt relief.
Profit takers took aim at Canadian bank stocks which have soared to new heights in recent weeks. Overall, declining stocks outnumbered advances 523 to 456 with 262 issues flat.
* Among active bank stocks, Royal Bank of Canada lost 0.55 to close at 39.15 on 2.7 million shares. Bank of Nova Scotia fell 0.50 to 38.80 on 2.4 million shares.
* Provigo Inc. eased 0.15 to 6.25 on 3.3 million shares. The Quebec-based food retailer announced an aggressive expansion of its company-owned stores on Wednesday.
* In precious metals, Barrick Gold Corp. dropped 1.30 to 34.60 on 1.6 million shares. Franco-Nevada Mining Corp. Ltd. spiralled down 2.25 to close at 50.75.
* Alphanet Telecom gained 1.25 to 22.50 after announcing plans for a long distance telephone service via the Internet.
